diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including alopecia, pleural effusion, and arthritis that can include synovitis. It can also lead to neurological manifestations that can present as delirium. Dyspigmentation may occur due to skin involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can lead to pleural effusions, alopecia, and dyspigmentation of the skin. Delirium is less common but may occur if there are systemic complications or as a side effect of medications used in treatment.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD presents with features of various connective tissue diseases, including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, making it a potential diagnosis with this symptom complex. Symptoms can include synovitis, pleural effusions, and dyspigmentation. Neurological involvement and skin changes like alopecia are also observed.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primary Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth but can present with systemic features like arthralgia (potentially synovitis), pleural effusion, and alopecia. Neurological involvement can lead to symptoms such as delirium, though it's less common.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily known for its impact on joints, including synovitis, rheumatoid arthritis can also cause pleural effusion and has been associated with skin manifestations, such as dyspigmentation and alopecia. Systemic involvement might lead to neurological symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This disease involves abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs. It can lead to pleural effusion, and although less common, skin involvement can cause dyspigmentation and alopecia. Neurological involvement, leading to symptoms like delirium, is known as neurosarcoidosis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted through tick bites, Lyme disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, depending on the stage. Early disseminated Lyme disease can cause arthritis (synovitis), neurological disorders (eg. delirium), and less commonly, skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include skin changes (including dyspigmentation and alopecia), arthritis (synovitis), and neurological symptoms (including delirium). Pleural effusion is less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders involves inflammation of blood vessels, which can restrict blood flow and damage organs. Specific types like Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis) can cause pleural effusions, skin changes, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This form of lupus is caused by certain prescription drugs. It often presents with symptoms similar to SLE, such as pleural effusion, alopecia, and potentially synovitis. Delirium and dyspigmentation may also be observed if the nervous system and skin are involved.

diagnoses: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) Infection
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Systemic lupus erythematosus)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the development of urticaria (hives) without a known cause, which can be associated with dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Gastritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the stomach lining, often resulting in dyspepsia and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenitis, decreased appetite, and potentially impact growth and development leading to delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as decreased appetite and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Eating Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions characterized by abnormal eating habits, which can lead to decreased appetite and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome can cause lymphadenitis and affect the body’s nutritional status, leading to decreased appetite and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, often presenting with dyspepsia and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, presenting with dyspepsia, decreased appetite, and can affect growth in children.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time, which can affect nutritional status, leading to decreased appetite and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Anorexia Nervosa
diagnoses.description: An eating disorder characterized by an abnormally low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted perception of body weight, often leading to decreased appetite and delayed puberty.

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. This could explain symptoms like hypermobility and possibly postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects circulation (blood flow). It involves the nervous system and is characterized by the body's inability to properly regulate blood flow and blood pressure, leading to lightheadedness, fainting, and rapid heartbeat, especially when standing up.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia — a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Iron deficiency anemia is caused by insufficient iron, leading to hypoferritinemia. Symptoms can include fatigue and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as 'mono' or the 'kissing disease,' this infection can cause lymphadenitis, fatigue, and possibly influence the severity or manifestation of symptoms like chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body. It’s characterized by periods of illness (flares) and remissions. It can present with chest pain, fatigue, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the excessive release of mast cell mediators. Symptoms can mimic allergic reactions and include chest pain, flushing, and potentially contribute to POTS.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, heart palpitations indicative of POTS, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Small Fiber Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the small sensory cutaneous nerves, often associated with autonomic dysfunction like POTS. Symptoms can include pain, tingling, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, contributing to hypermobility. Patients may also experience cardiovascular symptoms, including chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Myalgic Encephalomyelitis/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (ME/CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex, chronic, debilitating disorder characterized by profound fatigue, sleep abnormalities, pain, and other symptoms that are made worse by exertion. It can be connected with immune dysfunction, which could theoretically interact with conditions like POTS and lymphadenitis.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Anxiety or panic attacks inducing hyperventilation
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines can lead to aura, which might explain symptoms like aphasia and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including aphasia, numbness, and headaches, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include aphasia, numbness, and severe headache. It is a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, numbness, and in severe cases, sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause seizures, headaches, brain fog, aphasia, and numbness depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system where the immune system attacks the myelin sheath. It can lead to symptoms such as numbness, aphasia, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. It can sometimes present with headache and aphasia post-seizure.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, phonophobia, aphasia, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A focal collection within the brain tissues, filled with pus. Symptoms can mimic those of many other conditions and can include headaches, seizures, aphasia, and neurological deficits such as numbness.

diagnoses.name: Neurosyphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection of the brain or spinal cord that can occur if syphilis is not treated. Symptoms can vary widely and may include headache, aphasia, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may manifest as visual disturbances, sensory symptoms, or speech disturbances before the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without aura
diagnoses.description: A common condition characterized by episodic attacks of headache with symptoms such as nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia, but without neurological aura.

diagnoses.name: Cluster headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that presents with severe headaches on one side of the head. It may be associated with autonomic symptoms but is not typically associated with aura or prolonged aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Tension-type headache
diagnoses.description: This is the most common type of primary headache. Symptoms include a dull, non-pulsating pain on both sides of the head, which may be associated with photophobia or phonophobia but not typically with aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a TIA may manifest with headache, aphasia, or other neurological deficits, which are typically temporary and fully resolve within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can cause headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits such as aphasia. Symptoms depend on the tumor's location and size.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can cause severe headache, fever, confusion, and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding into the space around the brain can cause a sudden, severe headache, photophobia, and sometimes loss of consciousness or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke can lead to symptoms like sudden numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, trouble speaking or understanding speech (aphasia), and headache.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, which can cause severe headache, photophobia, phonophobia, seizures, and neurological deficits, including aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are headaches with sensory disturbances. Common symptoms include visual disturbances (scintillation), difficulty speaking (aphasia), and sensitivity to light (photophobia).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA presents with symptoms similar to a stroke, including temporary aphasia, parasthesia, and sometimes visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke can cause sudden dysphagia, aphasia, and parasthesia, depending on the area of the brain that is affected. Prompt medical attention is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a disease where the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include dysphagia, parasthesia, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can cause severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can present diverse symptoms based on their location and size, including aphasia, dysphagia, and parasthesia.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control and leading to symptoms like dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Early symptoms include weakness and tingling in your extremities (parasthesia).

diagnoses.name: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
diagnoses.description: An immune mediated disease of brain. It usually occurs after viral infection and can present with aphasia, parasthesia, and sometimes photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Optic Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause partial or complete loss of vision, eye pain, and in some cases, symptoms like photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound. Aura symptoms can include visual disturbances (scintillations), speech or language problems (aphasia), and sensory or motor disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can cause headache, dizziness, temporary vision loss (including phenomena similar to scintillations), and difficulty speaking (including aphasia), but no lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, inability to move or feel on one side of the body, problems understanding or speaking (aphasia), and seeing problems in one or both eyes.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be cancerous or benign. Symptoms can include headaches, nausea, seizures, and cognitive or speech disturbances such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, usually due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, fever, stiff neck, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Some forms can present with aphasic or visual sensory symptoms similar to migraine aura.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive crisis
diagnoses.description: A severe increase in blood pressure that can lead to a stroke. Symptoms may include severe headache, nausea, vision problems, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Chemical poisoning (e.g., carbon monoxide)
diagnoses.description: Exposure to toxic chemicals can lead to a range of symptoms including headache, nausea, dizziness, and confusion. Depending on the substance, it might also induce visual disturbances or speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety or panic disorders
diagnoses.description: Although primarily psychological in origin, severe anxiety or panic attacks can manifest with physical symptoms including headache, nausea, dizziness, and transient speech issues such as difficulty finding words.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can be wide-ranging and may include fatigue, walking difficulties, numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and issues with vision or speech.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Viral infections (other than HIV or Hepatitis C)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Bacterial infections (e.g., Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome)
Cancer (metastasis or primary in relation to pericardial or pleural involvement)
